answers.answer: Upper left abdominal area symptoms usually stem from the large intestine.  Are you having any intestinal symptoms - increased gas, pain, change in bowel habits?  Is it sore when you push on the area?As for the diabetes, did your neuropathy just start recently?  If it were me, I would talk to my doctor about starting a low carbohydrate diet (if you are type 2 diabetic).  If you are on insulin, you MUST tell your doctor if you want to do the low carb diet - they have to adjust your insulin according to your diet.  When you eat a low carbohydrate diet, you don't need much insulin from your pancreas to help with blood sugar elevations, because your blood sugar should stay pretty level on this diet.I've mentioned to several diabetics I know to try the gluten free diet (gluten is in wheat, barley, rye and possibly oats) for their neuropathy.  At first, their neuropathy hurt more.  But it improved with time.  They were amazed!I hate to see diabetics rely on medications to control their symptoms, especially for the neuropathy.  Maybe, if you'd like, read up on the gluten free diet and see if you'd like to give it a try.  You might find that your "swelling" feeling goes away on the above diets.I hope this helps or someone is able to help you.  Hang in there.
